tasks.question: Continuous outcome prediction model: sample size with R-squared=0.2. What is the required sample size?

A gerontologist is evaluating a rapid antigen test for respiratory infections. The expected sensitivity is 0.9 and the clinically acceptable margin (delta) is 0.1. At significance level 0.05 with 80% power, how many diseased subjects are needed to confirm that the true sensitivity exceeds 0.8?

A sports medicine physician is evaluating a new blood biomarker panel for early cancer detection. The expected sensitivity is 0.85 and the clinically acceptable margin (delta) is 0.1. At significance level 0.05 with 80% power, how many diseased subjects are needed to confirm that the true sensitivity exceeds 0.75?

A allergist is evaluating a point-of-care screening tool for cardiac events. The expected sensitivity is 0.9 and the clinically acceptable margin (delta) is 0.05. At significance level 0.05 with 80% power, how many diseased subjects are needed to confirm that the true sensitivity exceeds 0.85?

A urologist is evaluating an imaging-based diagnostic for neurological disorders. The expected sensitivity is 0.95 and the clinically acceptable margin (delta) is 0.05. At significance level 0.05 with 90% power, how many diseased subjects are needed to confirm that the true sensitivity exceeds 0.9?

A hematologist is evaluating a serological assay for autoimmune conditions. The expected specificity is 0.9 and the clinically acceptable margin (delta) is 0.1. At significance level 0.05 with 80% power, how many diseased subjects are needed to confirm that the true specificity exceeds 0.8?

A clinical nutritionist is evaluating a genomic screening test for hereditary conditions. The expected specificity is 0.95 and the clinically acceptable margin (delta) is 0.05. At significance level 0.05 with 90% power, how many diseased subjects are needed to confirm that the true specificity exceeds 0.9?

A rehabilitation specialist is evaluating a novel urinalysis panel for renal disease. The expected sensitivity is 0.9 with a clinically acceptable margin (delta) of 0.1. With 100 diseased subjects available, what power does the study achieve at significance level 0.05?

A pediatrician is designing a study to validate the AUC of an AI-assisted imaging tool for fracture detection. The expected AUC is 0.8 and the minimum acceptable AUC margin (delta) is 0.1. At significance level 0.05 with 80% power, how many subjects are needed to show the AUC significantly exceeds 0.7?

A endocrinologist is designing a study to validate the AUC of a saliva-based screening for metabolic disorders. The expected AUC is 0.9 and the minimum acceptable AUC margin (delta) is 0.05. At significance level 0.05 with 80% power, how many subjects are needed to show the AUC significantly exceeds 0.85?

A orthopedic surgeon is designing a study to validate the AUC of a wearable sensor for arrhythmia detection. The expected AUC is 0.75 and the minimum acceptable AUC margin (delta) is 0.1. At significance level 0.05 with 90% power, how many subjects are needed to show the AUC significantly exceeds 0.65?

A gastroenterologist needs to validate the sensitivity of a rapid antigen test for respiratory infections. The expected sensitivity is 0.9 with an acceptable deviation (delta) of 0.1. At significance level 0.05 with 80% power, how many truly positive subjects are needed?

A pulmonologist needs to validate the specificity of a new blood biomarker panel for early cancer detection. The expected specificity is 0.9 with an acceptable deviation (delta) of 0.1. At significance level 0.05 with 80% power, how many truly negative subjects are needed?

A rheumatologist needs to validate the sensitivity of a point-of-care screening tool for cardiac events. The expected sensitivity is 0.95 with an acceptable deviation (delta) of 0.05. At significance level 0.05 with 80% power, how many truly positive subjects are needed?
A nurse researcher wants to estimate a parameter of interest with a specified 95% confidence interval precision. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A social scientist wants to estimate a parameter of interest with a specified 95% confidence interval precision. How many subjects are needed for this precision?

A gerontologist is developing a clinical prediction model for a binary outcome. The model includes 20 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.25. The expected outcome prevalence is 15%. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?

A sports medicine physician is developing a clinical prediction model for a binary outcome. The model includes 10 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.15. The expected outcome prevalence is 10%. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?

A allergist is developing a clinical prediction model for a binary outcome. The model includes 15 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.2. The expected outcome prevalence is 20%. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?

A urologist is developing a clinical prediction model for a binary outcome. The model includes 30 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.3. The expected outcome prevalence is 20%. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?

A hematologist is developing a clinical prediction model for a binary outcome. The model includes 15 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.2. The expected outcome prevalence is 5%. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?

A clinical nutritionist is developing a clinical prediction model for a binary outcome. The model includes 25 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.1. The expected outcome prevalence is 30%. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?

A rehabilitation specialist is developing a clinical prediction model for a binary outcome. The model includes 20 candidate predictors. The expected outcome prevalence is 15%. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?

A occupational therapist is developing a clinical prediction model for a binary outcome. The model includes 24 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.288. The expected outcome prevalence is 17%. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?

A speech pathologist is developing a clinical prediction model for a binary outcome. The model includes 24 candidate predictors. The expected outcome prevalence is 17%. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?

A physical therapist is developing a clinical prediction model for a binary outcome. The model includes 10 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.2. The expected outcome prevalence is 10%. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmsampsize)
pmsampsize(type="b", csrsquared=0.20, parameters=10, prevalence=0.10, shrinkage=0.95)

tasks.question: A nephrologist wants to externally validate a prediction model. The expected outcome prevalence is 20%. The model's C-statistic is 0.8. How many subjects are needed for adequate calibration and discrimination assessment?

A infectious disease specialist wants to externally validate a prediction model. The expected outcome prevalence is 15%. The model's C-statistic is 0.75. How many subjects are needed for adequate calibration and discrimination assessment?

A psychologist wants to externally validate a prediction model. The expected outcome prevalence is 30%. The model's C-statistic is 0.7. How many subjects are needed for adequate calibration and discrimination assessment?

A educational researcher wants to externally validate a prediction model. The expected outcome prevalence is 20%. The model's C-statistic is 0.8. How many subjects are needed for adequate calibration and discrimination assessment?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmvalsampsize)
pmvalsampsize(type="b", prevalence=0.20, cstatistic=0.80, lpnormal=c(-1.5, 2.0), oeciwidth=0.40, cstatciwidth=0.10)
